>Hello:
>
>I've done some searching through the archives for this, but
>unfortunately, I couldn't find an answer to this question - I must
>admit, there were a large number of search results returned, so I may
>have missed something.
>
>My question is this - does jUnit instantiate my TestCase class for
>each test method that I have?  

Yes, it does. If my article "JUnit: A Starter Guide" didn't mention
that explicitly, then that's a defect in my article. To be sure, Kent's
original article, the one in which he introduced SUnit, says that
plainly. I suggest you read it -- it provides the best insight into why
xUnit is the way it is.

>A team member believes this is the case and this is potentially
>causing a problem with our current approach to writing automated test
>cases.  Our tests are around a server which is started and configured
>such that the tests can run against the server.  We're currently
>starting and configuring the server as part of the base test class's
>constructor, but since we don't currently allow more than one instance
>of our server to be running at a time, we cough up some errors.

Never, ever, ever do stuff in the TestCase constructor. Ever. Ever.

Ever.

Use the setUp method *or* wrap the TestSuite in a TestSetup object.
Mike's FAQ explains this in detail, I believe.

Best of luck, Tom.
